ygData.subject: Re: Backpropagation and NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Andy, I have no problem with the idea of NEAT as a foundation upon which to build.  That s perfectly aligned with my view that there is more yet to accomplish.

Subject: Re: Backpropagation and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=Uks9dWOe9TkxBC87FLjw6tMfW3zfB3mZT85-6Bb8dZ372zTND7_r

Andy, I have no problem with the idea of NEAT as a foundation upon
which to=
 build.  That's perfectly aligned with my view that there is
more yet to ac=
complish.  

Let me respond to some of your specific points below.

--- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:

> 
> The issues you ra=
ise, though valid, appear disingenuous for two 
> reasons. First, if you ha=
d reviewed the contents and capabilities of 
> the Dakota toolkit, you woul=
d have discovered the issues as being 
> essentially addressed. Second, not=
 intending any disrespect, from 
> external appearances, your efforts appea=
r directed in other 
> directions than that of addressing your self admitte=
d areas of 
> concern.
> 
> From a review of literature on the subject, the=
re is a common 
> understanding that EA is computationally expensive and sl=
ow to 
> converge, but robust for global search in problem domains with 
> =
multiple local minima.
> 

It really just depends who you are talking about=
 whether there is a
"common understanding" about anything in AI.  It also d=
epends whether
we are talking about the past or the future.  

For example,=
 it's often said that "neural networks get caught on local
optima" (and the=
re is indeed a "common understanding" that they do)
but when people say tha=
t they are almost always only talking about
backprop, which is just one sin=
gle neural network learning algorithm.
 Backprop is not the only way a neur=
al network can learn.

The problem is that when we talk about methods in ma=
chine learning we
often confuse whether we are talking about a *field* or a=
 particular
method.  In the case of EAs, you seem to be talking about some
=
existing methods that have been analyzed (often by people who are not
even =
aware of the most modern approaches) in the past.   For example,
the old-fa=
shioned bit-string based simple EA has been analyzed
extensively.

Yet as a=
 field, EAs themselves are evolving.  Problems identified in
the past are a=
ctively being addressed in the present and future. Some
modern approaches c=
ompletely overturn the assumptions and problems of
the past (and of course =
introduce their own new problems).  Check out
Estimation of Distribution Al=
gorithms and the CMA-ES:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimation_of_distri=
bution_algorithm
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMA-ES

When I look at EAs, o=
r any research area for that matter, I always
think about what they *could*=
 be, rather than what they are.  And as a
researcher, I try to make them wh=
at they could be.  To me, that is the
exciting thing about research: At its=
 best, it overturns dogma.  I
like to view a limitation as a challenge rath=
er than as a brick wall.

> And that is from people who are working "hard" =
problems (i.e. multi-
> discipline, multiobjective, non-linear inequality c=
onstraints, etc.), 
> at government laboratories and Fortune 100 defense fi=
rms. Not dancing 
> rag-dolls and computer-aided art.
> 

First, while you =
often cite multiobjective optimization as a "hard
problem" for EAs, in fact=
 some of the most effective algorithms in
multiobjective optimization are E=
As.  EAs are naturally suited to
maintaining a pareto front because a paret=
o front requires a
population to hold it.  There is vast literature on pare=
to
optimization in EAs, both in multiobjective optimization and in
coevolut=
ion.  Here are some seminal examples:

K. Deb, A. Pratap, S. Agarwal, and T=
. Meyarivan. A Fast and Elitist
Multiobjective Genetic Algorithm: NSGA-II. =
IEEE Transactions on
Evolutionary Computation, 6(2):182=96197, 2002.
http:/=
/citeseer.ist.psu.edu/530140.html

De Jong, E.D. (2004). The Incremental Pa=
reto-Coevolution Archive.
Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Compu=
tation Conference
GECCO-04, pp. 525-536. 
http://people.cs.uu.nl/dejong/pub=
lications/gecco04coev.pdf

in fact, some of the most brilliant theorists in=
 pareto optimization
are in evolutionary computation.

As for NEAT in gover=
nment research labs on "serious" problems, here is
an example:

Shimon Whit=
eson and Daniel Whiteson (2007). "Stochastic Optimization
for Collision Sel=
ection in High Energy Physics". IAAI 2007:
Proceedings of the Nineteenth An=
nual Innovative Applications of
Artificial Intelligence Conference. 
=
http://arxiv.org/PS_cache/hep-ex/pdf/0607/0607012v1.pdf

The article itself=
 states, "These NEAT selectors are currently in use
at FermiLab for selecti=
ng collisions from real data collected
with the Tevatron collider."  So, th=
ere you go, NEAT is being used at
FermiLab itself to select which particle =
collisions are most promising.

When you mention rag dolls and art, you're =
giving me an opportunity to
comment on some of our own current research.  O=
ur group has indeed
recently produced a number of works in interactive evol=
ution,
including dance, art, music, and particle effects.  Perhaps it may
s=
eem a somewhat lighthearted departure from more serious subjects.

Yet the =
implications of this work are as serious as any in my view. 
All of that wo=
rk is a probe of the ubiquity of patterns and
regularities, in particular t=
hrough the theory of CPPNs.  The deeper
lesson in that body of work is that=
 the very same encoding is able to
produce patterns appropriate to what wou=
ld otherwise appear to be
disparate domains.  The idea is to develop a theo=
ry of generic pattern
generation and to show that patterns are interchangea=
ble across many
domains.  That insight leads to the idea of HyperNEAT, whic=
h takes
again the very same encoding that is producing art and music and us=
es
it to produce a large-scale neural pattern.  Therein it becomes
serious,=
 because the hard problems you like to focus on almost always
involve patte=
rns and regularities.  

It is no accident that in building a theory of pat=
tern generation, a
number of interactive evolutionary computation experimen=
ts would need
to be performed because understanding the capabilities of a p=
attern
generator require *exploring* the space of possibilities rather than=

simply optimizing, and humans are much better explorers than
computers.  T=
he theory would never have gotten off the ground if we
had stuck to more tr=
aditional optimization problems.   Indeed, as
funny as it sounds, the whole=
 idea began to materialize only after I
evolved a spaceship in Mattias Fage=
rlund's DelphiNEAT.  

To put it starkly, without that exploration in genet=
ic art, there
would have been no HyperNEAT.  And in fact even more new theo=
ries with
practical implications are coming (not yet published) because of
=
phenomena that became apparent through Picbreeder.  So you see, in
building=
 a new algorithm or a new theory with practical implications,
often traditi=
onal problems are exactly the wrong vehicle to discovery
because they perpe=
tuate the same dogmatic perspectives that already
permeate the field to beg=
in with and cause it to be staying in one
place.   Thus all of these applic=
ations are chosen with careful
scrutiny with a sincere belief in their prac=
tical ramifications.

Not to mention the fact that interactive evolution it=
self has the
practical potential to change the way we do engineering in som=
e cases.
 Can you imagine Picbreeder for furinute instead of pictures?  Or =
for
cars?  Someday that may be how we create highly customized artifacts.
 =
  In fact, some of the problems to which you are referring (highly
nonlinea=
r and multi-objective) may only be possible to solve through
interactive ev=
olution.

> How many times has NEAT, as a monolithic approach, been cited a=
nd 
> successfully applied by government laboratories and Fortune 100 
> de=
fense firms for these type of "hard" problems?
> 

You can refer to the pap=
er on high-energy physics at FermiLab if
you're interested, but I still thi=
nk there is a bigger picture.  

In some ways, as researchers in AI, what p=
ractitioners are using to
solve hard problems is exactly what we *don't* wa=
nt to use.  After
all, how is anything ever going to become more powerful i=
f we just
look to practitioners to show us what methods we should be using?=
  As
researchers, it is our job to give the practitioners *new* options,
no=
t the other way around.

Practitioners are often several steps behind algor=
ithm developers, and
with good reason.  They often can't afford to take big=
 risks and need
something practical in the here and now.   You will therefo=
re find
that most cutting-edge algorithms are not in use in industry or as
=
tools in other scientific disciplines at the very moment that they are
cutt=
ing-edge.  Yet someone has to be developing the algorithms of the
future.

=
ken
